title: Dussehra: The Day Evil Burned in Plain Sight
excerpt: Every year, an effigy of a ten-headed demon king is stuffed with firecrackers and set ablaze before thousands of watching eyes. Dussehra is the most theatrical festival in the Hindu calendar ‚Äî and also the most honest. It does not whisper that evil was defeated. It roars it.

body.heading: Ravana: The Villain Who Was Not Stupid
body.text: To understand Dussehra, you must resist the temptation to see Ravana as a simple cartoon villain. He was not. Ravana was a scholar of extraordinary depth ‚Äî a master of the Vedas and Upanishads, a musician of divine skill (he invented the ravanhattha, an early string instrument), a devotee of Shiva so intense that he cut off his own head ten times as an offering. He was also the king of Lanka ‚Äî a kingdom described in the Ramayana as literally golden, a civilization of unsurpassed splendor. His flaw ‚Äî the flaw that brought everything down ‚Äî was a single moment of unrestrained desire: the abduction of Sita. One act of injustice, committed by a brilliant man who should have known better. The Ramayana is not a story about a stupid monster being defeated. It is a story about what happens when one catastrophic moral failure ‚Äî born of ego and unchecked desire ‚Äî brings down a great man and his entire civilization. Ravana's ten heads are traditionally interpreted as ten forms of ego: lust, anger, pride, envy, greed, delusion, attachment, fear, jealousy, and hatred. On Dussehra, it is not Ravana who burns. It is these.

body.heading: The Ramlila: Drama as Devotion
body.text: In the days leading up to Dussehra ‚Äî particularly in northern India ‚Äî the Ramlila is performed. This is a dramatic re-enactment of the Ramayana story, staged in open grounds across the city over nine nights. Local actors play Ram, Sita, Lakshmana, Hanuman, and Ravana. The sets are elaborate, the costumes are vivid, the audience is enormous ‚Äî tens of thousands watching, many of whom know every word of the story and still lean forward when Ram notches his arrow. The Ramlila of Ramnagar, near Varanasi, is perhaps the most famous: it has run without interruption for over two centuries, takes place across the entire city (with the audience moving from location to location as the story moves), and is considered a living heritage of extraordinary cultural depth. The Ramlila is not entertainment disguised as devotion. It is devotion expressed through the most human of all arts: storytelling.

body.heading: Vijayadashami: The Tenth Day of Victory
body.text: Dussehra falls on Vijayadashami ‚Äî the tenth day (Dashami) of the bright fortnight of Ashwin, immediately following the nine nights of Navratri. The name itself carries the meaning: 'Dasha' (ten) + 'Hara' (defeat). It is the day Ram defeated Ravana ‚Äî ten-headed, immensely powerful, seemingly indestructible Ravana ‚Äî after nine nights of war. It is also the day the goddess Durga completed her nine-night battle against Mahishasura and rested in triumph. Two great victories, landing on the same day. Vijayadashami is considered the most auspicious day of the year for new beginnings: for starting a new business, for purchasing a vehicle, for beginning the study of a new instrument or art form, for any venture that requires courage and the confidence of divine favor. The Sanskrit word 'Vijaya' means not merely 'win' ‚Äî it means 'complete conquest.' On Dussehra, the tradition says: start something you intend to finish.

body.heading: The Burning of the Effigies
body.text: As dusk falls on Dussehra, vast effigies of Ravana ‚Äî often forty to sixty feet tall, stuffed with firecrackers ‚Äî are set alight in open grounds across the country. Some cities compete to build the tallest effigy; some neighborhoods build spectacular constructions with moving parts; the city of Mysore stages one of the most magnificent Dussehra processions in the world, culminating with the burning of Ravana's effigy before an audience of hundreds of thousands. The burning is always timed to the precise moment of Ram's victory ‚Äî the arrow is loosed (often by a performer dressed as Ram, with a flaming arrow), and the effigy erupts in a cascade of fire and sound that shakes the ground. There is something cathartic in this spectacle that no amount of theological explanation can fully capture. To watch evil burn ‚Äî loudly, publicly, completely ‚Äî and to cheer: this is ancient theatre doing what theatre has always done at its best. Not merely entertaining, but healing.

body.heading: What Dussehra Is Really Celebrating
body.text: On a personal level, Dussehra is an invitation to identify your own Ravana ‚Äî the specific form of ego or desire or fear that, like Ravana's ten heads, keeps regrowing every time you think you have defeated it. The festival acknowledges something important: that evil is not exotic. It does not live only in demon kings with ten heads. It lives in ordinary moments of pride, of cruelty, of refusing to see the harm we cause. The burning of the effigy is public and spectacular because the acknowledgment of our failures should be as loud as our celebrations of success. Dussehra is also, crucially, a celebration of patience: Ram did not defeat Ravana in a day. He walked to Lanka, he built a bridge, he fought a war. He kept going. Vijayadashami is the tenth day ‚Äî and it arrives only after nine very hard nights. The tradition does not promise easy victories. It promises that if you do not stop, the tenth day comes.
